name: Eyes Right
description:
I was sorting through some snaps I had taken at the Tate Modern, when I spotted this image: the subject wasn't foregrounded in the shot, but I was struck by the slightly hesitant, self-absorbed expression. What was this person thinking or feeling, and was it prompted by anything he had seen at the gallery?

Giclee print on A3+ Photorag 308gsm archival grade paper.

name: Look
description:
A visit to the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) in downtown Los Angeles prompted me to start painting gallery scenes. I was struck by the effect of the flat light, and the way people held themselves when paying a particular kind of attention. This is my wife Claire and son Lewis.

Giclee print on A3+ Photorag 308gsm archival grade paper.

name: Enlighten Me
description:
I like the Turner Contemporary gallery in Margate, and especially the vast downstairs space that overlooks the sea and is flooded with light when the sun shines. The Juan Munoz sculptures were particularly dramatic when I visited on such a day, as were the folk who stood around and discussed them.

Giclee print on A3+ Photorag 308gsm archival grade paper.

name: Chance Meeting
description:
This is based on a photograph taken on a visit with old friends to the Tate Modern, London, in 2013. I've got into the habit of taking a camera with me on such visits - not because I expect to take good pictures, but because if you take enough you might capture people doing something interesting in an unguarded moment. Just what is being negotiated here?

Giclee print on A3+ Photorag 308gsm archival grade paper.

name: Line, Light, Love
description:
A few years ago the painter Paul Warburton visited Whitstable, with the (now sadly gone) Caxton gallery exhibiting some of the pictures of the coast he completed whilst he was here. I would have bought some had I been able to afford them.

Rendered in charcoal tempered by swathes of white paint, his pictures were as moody and dramatic as they were simple. This is one of my most recent efforts to bend that aesthetic and method to my own interests.

Giclee print on A3+ Photorag 308gsm archival grade paper.
